factoid: Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "I knew the princess at once."
Princess Mary exclaimed, "And I had no idea!"
Princess Mary said to Andrew, "Ah, Andrew, I did not see you."
Prince Andrew and Princess Mary kissed each other hand in hand.
Prince Andrew told Princess Mary that she was still the same crybaby as ever.
Princess Mary turned toward Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary's large luminous eyes looked lovingly and gently at Prince Andrew's face.
Princess Mary was looking at Prince Andrew with a beautiful look at that moment.
Princess Mary talked incessantly.
Princess Mary's short downy upper lip touched her rosy lower lip when necessary.
Princess Mary's lip drew up again when her face broke into a smile of glittering teeth and sparkling eyes.
Princess Mary told them about an accident they had had on Spásski Hill.
The accident might have been serious for Princess Mary in her condition.
Princess Mary informed them that she had left all her clothes in Petersburg.
Princess Mary said that heaven knows what she would have to dress in here.
Princess Mary said that Andrew had quite changed.
Princess Mary said that Kitty Odýntsova had married an old man.
Princess Mary said that there was a suitor for Mary, a real one.
Princess Mary said that they would talk about that later.
Princess Mary was still looking silently at Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary's beautiful eyes were full of love and sadness.
Princess Mary was following a train of thought independent of Lise's words.
While describing the last Petersburg fete, Princess Mary addressed Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary asked, "So you are really going to the war, Andrew?"
Lise sighed too.
Prince Andrew replied, "Yes and even tomorrow."
Prince Andrew said, "He is leaving me here, God knows why, when he might have had promotion."
Princess Mary did not listen to the end of Prince Andrew's speech.
Princess Mary continued her train of thought and turned to Lise with a tender glance at her figure.
Princess Mary asked Lise, "Is it certain?"
Princess Mary's face changed.
Princess Mary sighed and said, "Yes, quite certain. Ah! it is very dreadful."
Princess Mary's lip descended.
Princess Mary brought her face close to Lise's face.
Princess Mary unexpectedly began to cry again.
Prince Andrew said, "She needs rest."
Prince Andrew said, "Don't you, Lise? Take her to your room and I'll go to Father. How is he? Just the same?"
Princess Mary answered, "Yes, just the same. Though I don't know what your opinion will be."
Prince Andrew asked, "And are the hours the same? And the walks in the avenues? And the lathe?"
Prince Andrew smiled scarcely perceptibly.
Prince Andrew was aware of his weaknesses.
Princess Mary said, "The hours are the same, and the lathe, and also the mathematics and my geometry lessons."
Princess Mary said this gleefully, as if her lessons in geometry were among the greatest delights of her life.
When the twenty minutes had elapsed and the time had come for Prince Tikhon to get up, Tíkhon came to call Prince Andrew to his father.
Prince Tikhon departed from his usual routine in honor of Prince Andrew's arrival.
Prince Tikhon gave orders to admit Prince Andrew to his apartments while he dressed for dinner.
Prince Tikhon always dressed in old-fashioned style, wearing an antique coat and powdered hair.
When Prince Andrew entered Prince Tikhon's dressing room, he did not wear the contemptuous look and manner he wore in drawing rooms, but he had an animated face with which he talked to Pierre.
Prince Tikhon was sitting on a large leather-covered chair, wrapped in a powdering mantle, entrusting his head to Tíkhon.
Prince Tikhon said, "Ah! here's the warrior! Wants to vanquish Buonaparte?"
Prince Tikhon shook his powdered head as much as the tail, which Tíkhon was holding fast to plait, would allow.
Prince Tikhon said, "You at least must tackle him properly, or else if he goes on like this he'll soon have us, too, for his subjects! How are you?"
Prince Tikhon held out his cheek.
Prince Tikhon was in a good temper after his nap before dinner.
Prince Tikhon used to say that a nap after dinner was silver—before dinner, golden.
Prince Tikhon cast happy sidelong glances at Prince Andrew from under his thick bushy eyebrows.
Prince Andrew went up and kissed Prince Tikhon on the spot indicated to him.
Prince Andrew made no reply on Prince Tikhon's favorite topic—making fun of the military men of the day, and more particularly of Bonaparte.
